Facility Description



EnviroTech operates one process in its Helena, Arkansas facility that are subject to the requirements of both the Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Management standards (29 CFR 1910.119).  The process, BromMax, uses bromine and chlorine as raw materials in the manufacture of stabilized bromine salts.  In this process, bromine is received in bulk and stored in one 1,000 gallon and one 2,400 gallon storage tanks prior to use in the process.  Chlorine is received, stored, and used from one ton cylinders.  Up to two cylinders may be connected to the process at any one time.  The bromine and chlorine are then used in a reactor vessel to make the final product.  The covered process includes the storage and handling of the bromine and chlorine up through the reactor vessel.



EnviroTech also operates a process at the Helena facility to manufacture peracetic acid.  In the previous RMP submittal this was included as a covered process due to the fact that the product contains more than 1% of peracetic acid which is a RMP listed chemical.  However, the RMP rule also states that if the partial pressure of a listed substance in a mixture is less than 10 mmHg, the process containing that mixture is not subject to the RMP requirements.  EnviroTech has determined through calculation that the maximum partial pressure of the peracetic acid in the solutions at the facility is 2.68 mmHg.  Therefore, this process is no longer included in this submittal. 



Environmental, Health, and Safety Policy



EnviroTech's commitment to providing a safe, healthy work environment for employees as well as providing a safe, healthy environment for the surrounding community is the primary goal of EnviroTech's management. The properties of chlorine and bromine, as well as other chemicals in use in the facility, make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions

to prevent human exposures to hazardous concentrations, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  EnviroTech management and employees are committed to compliance with all regulations that are applicable to the facility, including those under the RMP and PSM rules.



Accidental Release Prevention Program Overview



The Helena facility complies with the Program 3 requirements of the RMP programs through the implementation of a program for process safety intended to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. This is a comprehensive program with elements that include development of process safety information appropriate to the process, process hazard analysis, employee training, operating procedures, mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, contractor safety, emergency planning and response, compliance auditing, safe work procedures, and employee participation.



The program ensures that the process and the equipment in the process is designed, constructed, operated, and maintained according to industry codes and standards and accepted good engineering practices.  Process hazards analyses have been conducted on EnviroTech processes to identify and characterize potential hazards in the processes and to develop control measures for the identified hazards.  Operating procedures have been prepared and training has been conducted for all affected employees.  A management of change process is used to insure that no hazards are introduced through any changes in chemicals, equipment, procedures or the operation of the processes. The mechanical integrity element of the program includes identification of critical equipment and scheduled inspections and tests of that equipment including storage and containment features as well as monitoring and control devices in the process to detect any deficiencies or defects in equipment.  Preventative main

tenance and replacement policies for parts and equipment ensure that deficiencies are addressed and corrected before they could potentially contribute to a release incident. All elements of the Process Safety Management Program help to minimize the potential for an uncontrolled release of hazardous chemicals. 



Emergency Response Program Overview



EnviroTech has developed an emergency response plan (in accordance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules at 29 CFR 1910.38 and 29 CFR 1910.120) that includes provisions to respond to chemical emergencies on-site with trained EnviroTech personnel and provisions to evacuate personnel from the facility in the event of an uncontrolled accidental release of a hazardous chemical. The emergency response program focuses on the following key elements: discovery and notification of a release or other incident, facility evacuation and head count procedures, mobilization of the appropriate response effort, coordination with local response agencies and authorities, identification of trained responders and incident commanders, post-incident recovery and clean-up procedures, media relations, and the conduct of training, drills and response critiques.  In addition to chemical releases the emergency response plan also addresses medical emergencies, fires and explosions, severe weather events, seismic events, and security events such as bomb threats, suspicious mail, unauthorized personnel on site, etc.



It is EnviroTech's policy to contact the local emergency response agencies, including the local fire department in the event of a hazardous chemical release. EnviroTech has coordinated with the local emergency planning committee on its emergency response plan, and in the unlikely event of an uncontrolled release, the local authorities will be notified by EnviroTech and a joint decision will be made on whether local areas will be evacuated. The local authorities will notify any affected neighbors or surroundin

g properties if an evacuation is necessary.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no incidents at the Helena facility involving bromine or chlorine in the last five years that meet the requirements for reporting in the five year history required for the RMP.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



EnviroTech is committed to continuous efforts to improve the safe operation of their processes by implementing preventative maintenance programs, inspection programs, and employee training in the safe operation of the equipment and the system. The processes are designed in accordance with good engineering practices.  The management of change process is used to evaluate any system changes or modifications to insure continued compliance with regulatory requirements and good engineering practices and identify any needed safety precautions prior to implementation of the changes.  In addition, periodic auditing of the prevention program is conducted to identify any needed improvements to procedures, systems or equipment.
